Welcome, Geoff! You’re back for the Fall 2019 semester to teach CS 125. Your students last Spring were moderately happy with your work, congrats! However, that means that your new batch of students and the university have high expectations from you to do a great job, yet again. This is your handy help page, informing you of the various tools that’ll aid you in teaching your class. Tap the subheading to get more info on them.

Your semester is divided into weeks. After planning the homework, quiz, midterm (if any), and MP checkpoint (if any), you’ll be able to go on to the next week using the button in the bottom right corner. While it’s recommended that you check the forum and your university email every week, it isn’t necessary for you to do so in order to go on to the next week.


In this course, you have two satisfaction bars: student satisfaction, and university satisfaction. You’re supposed to keep both: your students, and the university, happy. Based on your actions while teaching this class, the progress bars will go up or down. If, at any point, either of the bars hit zero, you automatically lose the game. As long as you keep the bars above zero, you’ll be able to reach the end of the semester and complete the game.


Every week, you’ll face a small challenge. This involves making a decision, which may not leave everybody happy. These decisions will usually be tradeoffs; for example, fulfilling the university’s wishes may disappoint your students. You must choose wisely.


You have three bonuses: Chuchu the dog or Xyz the cat, Ben Nordick the students’ main homie, and the real Geoff Challen. Each of them have a special power. 
Chuchu/Xyz boosts student satisfaction. 
The real Geoff Challen boosts university satisfaction. 
Ben Nordick, with his alpha Java powers, boosts both student and university satisfaction by a little bit. 
You can use each bonus only once per game.
This is where you’ll learn what your students feel about the course so far. It can be helpful to know where you’re going wrong, or what you’re doing correctly.

This is where you’ll periodically get email from the university, letting you know if they’re happy with what you’ve been doing. This, too, can be useful in pinpointing your errors to help you make the next week better.

Here, you’ll set the difficulty of the homework problems for the following week, from 0 to 9 (0 is the easiest, 9 is the hardest). There’ll be helpful advice on this page letting you know if the students think the homework has been too hard or too easy, so you can set the difficulty accordingly.

Here, you’ll set the difficulty of the quiz for the following week, from 0 to 9 (0 is the easiest, 9 is the hardest). There’ll be helpful advice on this page letting you know if the students think the midterms/quizzes have been too hard or too easy, so you can set the difficulty accordingly.

Midterms are held every five weeks, so this section will only be available in weeks 5, 10, and 15. Here, you’ll set the difficulty of the midterm for the following week, from 0 to 9 (0 is the easiest, 9 is the hardest). There’ll be helpful advice on this page letting you know if the students think the midterms/quizzes have been too hard or too easy, so you can set the difficulty accordingly.

MP checkpoints are added every two weeks, so this section will only be available every other week. MPs won’t be available in the first two weeks of the semester. If you’ve chosen the 15 week semester setting, there won’t be an MP checkpoint in the last week, either. Here, you’ll set the difficulty of the MP for the following week, from 0 to 9 (0 is the easiest, 9 is the hardest). There’ll be helpful advice on this page letting you know if the students think the MPs have been too hard or too easy, so you can set the difficulty accordingly.
